column3: the docker-compose provides different environments, each of which is used to deploy and test a code in a given programming languages. Therefore, the project needs multiple environments, each of which is for a given programming language

Microservices application that provides a platform for CI of minecraft games. They have different services that use the same image, but each service is invoked from a different component. In other words, each component uses a mysql database that is stored in a different environment
Microservices application for maps. Many services use the same image, but with different configurations; in particular the data and the commands (''command'' option)

Microservices application for software metrics. That is another example that uses similar images for different purposes. In this case, master and slave components (e.g. ,database). They also have a testing component.

column3: A web app that "... provides a friendly environment for productive development and testing of all Enqueue related features&packages". docker-compose is used to prepare and build different environments for testing different enqueue applications (e.g., one component for kafka, another one for rabitmq,…). Then, there is a main component that can deploy the application under test and that component connects to each of the other enqueue components. On top of that, it has the necessary infrastructure for web apps
column4: different environments for testing different enqueue (kafka, …) features. But, they are provided via a web app!!!

Docker-compose "is used to start the containers and set the env variables". They are using the same image for multiple components, each of which with a different configuration that servers different purposes. E.g., a Node image for emails, another node image for a front-end service. THese different configurations include different environment settings, different volumes
